title: Acts Chapter 8 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 8 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 8 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 8.

questions.question: Who was consenting unto Stephen's death, leading to a great persecution against the church in Jerusalem?
options: Saul
Peter
Philip
John
questions.correctAnswer: Saul
questions.explanation: Acts 8:1 states that Saul was consenting unto Stephen's death and that there was a great persecution against the church.

questions.question: What did devout men do for Stephen after his death?
options: Carried him to his burial and made great lamentation
Burned his body
Ignored him
Buried him secretly
questions.correctAnswer: Carried him to his burial and made great lamentation
questions.explanation: Acts 8:2 describes how devout men carried Stephen to his burial and made great lamentation over him.

questions.question: What was Saul doing to the church according to Acts 8:3?
options: Making havoc of the church
Preaching the gospel
Healing the sick
Writing letters
questions.correctAnswer: Making havoc of the church
questions.explanation: Acts 8:3 describes Saul making havoc of the church, entering into houses, and committing men and women to prison.

questions.question: What did those scattered abroad do after the persecution?
options: Went everywhere preaching the word
Stopped preaching
Fled to other countries
Became silent
questions.correctAnswer: Went everywhere preaching the word
questions.explanation: Acts 8:4 states that those scattered abroad went everywhere preaching the word.

questions.question: To which city did Philip go to preach Christ?
options: Samaria
Jerusalem
Caesarea
Azotus
questions.correctAnswer: Samaria
questions.explanation: Acts 8:5 says that Philip went down to the city of Samaria and preached Christ unto them.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the people in Samaria to Philip's preaching?
options: They gave heed with one accord
They rejected him
They ignored him
They arrested him
questions.correctAnswer: They gave heed with one accord
questions.explanation: Acts 8:6 states that the people with one accord gave heed to the things Philip spake.

questions.question: Which miracles did Philip perform in Samaria?
options: Casting out unclean spirits and healing palsies and lame
Raising the dead
Turning water into wine
Feeding thousands
questions.correctAnswer: Casting out unclean spirits and healing palsies and lame
questions.explanation: Acts 8:7 describes Philip casting out unclean spirits and healing many taken with palsies and those that were lame.

questions.question: What was the name of the man who had previously bewitched the people of Samaria with sorcery?
options: Simon
Philip
Saul
Peter
questions.correctAnswer: Simon
questions.explanation: Acts 8:9 identifies Simon as the man who used sorcery and bewitched the people of Samaria.

questions.question: True or False: Simon was baptized after believing Philip's preaching.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 8:13 confirms that Simon believed and was baptized.

questions.question: Who were sent by the apostles in Jerusalem to Samaria after they heard the word had been received there?
options: Peter and John
Paul and Barnabas
Philip and Stephen
James and Andrew
questions.correctAnswer: Peter and John
questions.explanation: Acts 8:14 states that Peter and John were sent to Samaria by the apostles in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What did Peter and John do when they came to Samaria?
options: Prayed for the people to receive the Holy Ghost
Baptized the people again
Preached to the Pharisees
Performed miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Prayed for the people to receive the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Acts 8:15 records that Peter and John prayed for the Samaritans to receive the Holy Ghost.

questions.question: What did Simon offer the apostles when he saw that the Holy Ghost was given through the laying on of their hands?
options: Money
Gifts
Food
Land
questions.correctAnswer: Money
questions.explanation: Acts 8:18 states that Simon offered money to the apostles to obtain the power to give the Holy Ghost by laying on of hands.

questions.question: True or False: Peter told Simon that the gift of God could be purchased with money.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 8:20 records Peter saying that Simon's money should perish because he thought the gift of God could be purchased with money.

questions.question: What did Philip do after the angel of the Lord spoke to him to go south toward Gaza?
options: Arise and go toward the way that goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza
Return to Jerusalem
Preach in Samaria
Go to Caesarea
questions.correctAnswer: Arise and go toward the way that goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza
questions.explanation: Acts 8:26 records the angel's instruction to Philip to go toward the south on the way from Jerusalem to Gaza.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The Ethiopian eunuch was reading the prophet ______ when Philip approached him.
options: Esaias
Jeremiah
Isaiah
Ezekiel
questions.correctAnswer: Esaias
questions.explanation: Acts 8:28-30 shows the eunuch reading the prophet Esaias, which is another name for Isaiah.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 8 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 8 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by persecution and wants to know how to continue witnessing effectively. Based on Acts 8, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Persecution scatters believers, but they continue preaching everywhere
Believers should avoid preaching when persecuted
Only the apostles should preach during trials
Persecution means God has abandoned His people
questions.correctAnswer: Persecution scatters believers, but they continue preaching everywhere
questions.explanation: Acts 8:1-4 shows that although the church was persecuted and scattered, those scattered preached the word everywhere, demonstrating perseverance and obedience in trials.

questions.question: How does Acts 8 teach us about the importance of faith and baptism in the life of a new believer?
options: Believers who accept the gospel are baptized after faith
Faith alone is enough without baptism
Baptism is optional for believers
Only apostles can baptize new believers
questions.correctAnswer: Believers who accept the gospel are baptized after faith
questions.explanation: Acts 8:12 and Acts 8:36-38 describe that those who believed Philip's message about Jesus were baptized, illustrating the biblical connection between faith and baptism as an expression of obedience.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to seek spiritual power for personal gain. What warning from Acts 8 would you share?
options: The gift of God cannot be purchased with money
Spiritual gifts are earned by good works
Money can buy spiritual influence
Seeking power is a sign of true faith
questions.correctAnswer: The gift of God cannot be purchased with money
questions.explanation: Simon’s attempt to buy the Holy Ghost (Acts 8:18-20) led to Peter’s rebuke that God’s gift is not for sale, teaching integrity and humility in spiritual matters.

questions.question: What does the example of Philip’s ministry in Samaria teach about evangelism and serving others?
options: Evangelism involves preaching, miracles, and serving the needy
Only teaching without action is effective
Evangelism should be done privately without signs
Serving others is unrelated to sharing the gospel
questions.correctAnswer: Evangelism involves preaching, miracles, and serving the needy
questions.explanation: Acts 8:5-8 describes Philip preaching Christ, performing miracles, and healing, showing a holistic approach to evangelism that includes compassion and power.

questions.question: How does Acts 8 illustrate the role of prayer in receiving the Holy Spirit?
options: The apostles prayed for new believers to receive the Holy Ghost
Receiving the Holy Spirit does not require prayer
Prayer is only for personal needs, not spiritual gifts
The Holy Spirit comes automatically without intercession
questions.correctAnswer: The apostles prayed for new believers to receive the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Acts 8:14-17 shows that Peter and John prayed for the Samaritan believers to receive the Holy Spirit, emphasizing the importance of prayer and intercession in spiritual growth.

questions.question: How does the story of Simon the sorcerer teach us about repentance and humility?
options: Simon was called to repent and pray for forgiveness
Simon was accepted without change
Pride is acceptable if one believes
Repentance is unnecessary after baptism
questions.correctAnswer: Simon was called to repent and pray for forgiveness
questions.explanation: Peter’s rebuke in Acts 8:21-23 calls Simon to repent and seek God’s forgiveness, teaching that humility and repentance are essential for a right heart before God.

questions.question: What principle about sharing the gospel can we learn from Philip’s encounter with the Ethiopian eunuch?
options: God guides believers to evangelize specific individuals
Evangelism should be limited to familiar groups
Only apostles are called to evangelize
Evangelism does not require understanding the listener’s needs
questions.correctAnswer: God guides believers to evangelize specific individuals
questions.explanation: Acts 8:26-29 shows the angel directing Philip to meet the eunuch, highlighting God’s guidance in personal evangelism and obedience to His leading.

questions.question: True or False: The eunuch in Acts 8 was baptized only after confessing his belief that Jesus is the Son of God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: According to Acts 8:37-38, the eunuch declared his belief in Jesus as the Son of God before Philip baptized him, showing the connection between faith and baptism.

questions.question: True or False: After Philip baptized the Ethiopian eunuch, the Spirit of the Lord immediately took Philip away, and the eunuch went on rejoicing.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 8:39 states the Spirit of the Lord caught away Philip after baptism, and the eunuch continued rejoicing, illustrating God’s supernatural work and the joy of salvation.

questions.question: A new believer is confused about understanding Scripture. Based on Acts 8, what advice would you give?
options: Seek guidance from a mature believer to understand the Bible
Try to understand Scripture alone without help
Ignore difficult scriptures
Only read the New Testament for understanding
questions.correctAnswer: Seek guidance from a mature believer to understand the Bible
questions.explanation: The Ethiopian eunuch asked Philip to explain the Scripture he was reading (Acts 8:30-31), showing the value of spiritual mentorship and teaching in understanding God’s Word.

questions.question: What does Acts 8 teach about the importance of integrity in one’s heart before God?
options: A right heart is necessary to have part in God’s work
External actions are enough without heartfelt integrity
Integrity is optional for believers
Only outward appearance matters to God
questions.correctAnswer: A right heart is necessary to have part in God’s work
questions.explanation: Peter told Simon his heart was not right with God and therefore had no part in the matter (Acts 8:21), emphasizing the importance of inner integrity and sincerity.

questions.question: How does Acts 8 demonstrate the role of joy in Christian life and evangelism?
options: Great joy accompanied the conversions and healings in Samaria
Joy is unrelated to evangelism
Believers should not be joyful during trials
Joy comes only after worldly success
questions.correctAnswer: Great joy accompanied the conversions and healings in Samaria
questions.explanation: Acts 8:8 records great joy in the city after many were healed and believed, illustrating how the gospel brings genuine joy and encouragement.

questions.question: A Christian is struggling with bitterness and sin. What counsel based on Acts 8 would you share?
options: Repent and pray for forgiveness to overcome bitterness
Ignore sins and continue as before
Bitterness is a sign of strong faith
Sin does not affect our relationship with God
questions.correctAnswer: Repent and pray for forgiveness to overcome bitterness
questions.explanation: Peter described Simon as being in the gall of bitterness and urged him to repent and pray for forgiveness (Acts 8:22-23), showing the path to healing through repentance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: After Philip preached the gospel in many cities, he was found at ______, and continued preaching until he reached Caesarea.
options: Azotus
Jerusalem
Samaria
Gaza
questions.correctAnswer: Azotus
questions.explanation: Acts 8:40 states that Philip was found at Azotus and preached in all the cities till he came to Caesarea, showing his ongoing commitment to evangelism.

questions.question: How does Acts 8 teach about the value of obedience to God’s direction in ministry?
options: Philip obeyed the angel’s command and went to Gaza, leading to a significant conversion
Disobedience in ministry has no consequences
Ministry should be done according to personal plans only
God does not guide believers in their ministry
questions.correctAnswer: Philip obeyed the angel’s command and went to Gaza, leading to a significant conversion
questions.explanation: In Acts 8:26-27, Philip obeyed the angel’s instruction to go toward Gaza, which resulted in the conversion of the Ethiopian eunuch, demonstrating the blessings of obedience.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 8 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 8.

questions.question: What event in Acts 8:1 led to the scattering of the believers throughout Judaea and Samaria?
options: A great persecution against the church in Jerusalem
A famine in Jerusalem
A Roman decree expelling Christians
An earthquake that destroyed the city
questions.correctAnswer: A great persecution against the church in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Acts 8:1 states that a great persecution against the church at Jerusalem caused the believers to be scattered throughout Judaea and Samaria.

questions.question: How did the people react to Philip’s preaching and miracles in Samaria?
options: They gave heed with one accord, hearing and seeing the miracles
They rejected him and imprisoned him
They debated among themselves without conviction
They only listened but did not believe
questions.correctAnswer: They gave heed with one accord, hearing and seeing the miracles
questions.explanation: Acts 8:6 describes that the people with one accord gave heed to Philip's message and miracles, showing unity and belief.

questions.question: Who was Simon, mentioned in Acts 8, and what was his previous occupation?
options: A man who used sorcery and bewitched the people of Samaria
A Roman centurion stationed in Samaria
A Jewish priest opposed to Philip
A Samaritan farmer who supported Philip
questions.correctAnswer: A man who used sorcery and bewitched the people of Samaria
questions.explanation: Acts 8:9 describes Simon as a man who practiced sorcery and had bewitched the people of Samaria before believing Philip.

questions.question: What was the significance of the apostles Peter and John laying hands on the believers in Samaria?
options: They received the Holy Ghost through the laying on of hands
They were ordained as new apostles
They were healed of physical illnesses
They were given the power to perform miracles
questions.correctAnswer: They received the Holy Ghost through the laying on of hands
questions.explanation: Acts 8:17 explains that when Peter and John laid hands on the believers, they received the Holy Ghost, indicating the impartation of the Spirit.

questions.question: What did Simon attempt to purchase from the apostles, and what was their response?
options: The power to give the Holy Ghost; Peter rebuked him for thinking God's gift could be bought
Land in Samaria; the apostles refused to sell it
A position of leadership; he was told to repent
A miracle to heal his sickness; they prayed for him instead
questions.correctAnswer: The power to give the Holy Ghost; Peter rebuked him for thinking God's gift could be bought
questions.explanation: Acts 8:18-20 recounts Simon offering money to buy the power to impart the Holy Ghost, and Peter rebuking him for his misguided intent.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in the scripture read by the Ethiopian eunuch that Philip explained?
options: He was led as a sheep to the slaughter, silent like a lamb before its shearer
He is a mighty lion roaring among the nations
He is a vine bringing forth abundant fruit
He is a shepherd guiding his flock
questions.correctAnswer: He was led as a sheep to the slaughter, silent like a lamb before its shearer
questions.explanation: Acts 8:32 describes the scripture as a metaphor of the suffering servant led like a sheep to slaughter, which Philip explained to the eunuch.

questions.question: In the context of Acts 8, what is the significance of the Ethiopian eunuch’s baptism?
options: It signifies the spread of the gospel beyond Jewish boundaries to Gentiles and foreigners
It was a political statement against Ethiopian royalty
It was a secret ritual only for Ethiopian officials
It represented the rejection of the Mosaic Law
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies the spread of the gospel beyond Jewish boundaries to Gentiles and foreigners
questions.explanation: The baptism of the Ethiopian eunuch in Acts 8:36-38 is emblematic of the gospel reaching beyond Israel to Gentiles, fulfilling Jesus' command to make disciples of all nations.

questions.question: What role did the angel of the Lord play in Philip’s mission according to Acts 8?
options: The angel directed Philip to go to the desert road toward Gaza
The angel gave Philip the power to perform miracles
The angel appeared to the Ethiopian eunuch
The angel rebuked Simon for his sorcery
questions.correctAnswer: The angel directed Philip to go to the desert road toward Gaza
questions.explanation: Acts 8:26 records an angel of the Lord instructing Philip to travel south on the road from Jerusalem to Gaza, guiding the mission's direction.

questions.question: What cultural or historical context helps explain the significance of the Ethiopian eunuch’s visit to Jerusalem?
options: He had traveled to Jerusalem to worship, indicating the inclusion of Gentiles in Jewish religious practice
He was a Roman official inspecting local governance
He was a Jewish pilgrim returning from exile
He was a merchant trading goods in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: He had traveled to Jerusalem to worship, indicating the inclusion of Gentiles in Jewish religious practice
questions.explanation: Acts 8:27 shows the eunuch came to Jerusalem to worship, which reflects the broader theme of Gentile inclusion in worship and later Christian mission.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the structure of Philip’s encounter with the Ethiopian eunuch in Acts 8:27-39?
options: Typology, where the eunuch’s reading of Isaiah foreshadows Christ’s sacrificial role
Chiasm, with symmetrical events centering on baptism
Parable, teaching through a story
Allegory, where every element symbolizes another concept
questions.correctAnswer: Typology, where the eunuch’s reading of Isaiah foreshadows Christ’s sacrificial role
questions.explanation: The passage includes typology as the eunuch reads Isaiah’s suffering servant passage, which foreshadows Jesus Christ’s death and redemption.

questions.question: How does Acts 8 demonstrate the theme of the Holy Spirit’s role in the early church?
options: By showing the Holy Spirit being received through laying on of hands after baptism
By emphasizing water baptism only without spiritual gifts
By focusing on angelic messages instead of the Spirit
By highlighting only miraculous healings without Spirit baptism
questions.correctAnswer: By showing the Holy Spirit being received through laying on of hands after baptism
questions.explanation: Acts 8:14-17 shows the early church’s practice of receiving the Holy Spirit by the apostles laying on of hands, emphasizing the Spirit’s empowering role.

questions.question: True or False: Simon the sorcerer was fully accepted by the apostles after his baptism without any admonition.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 8:20-23 records Peter rebuking Simon for trying to buy the power of the Holy Ghost, indicating Simon was admonished and told to repent.

questions.question: What does the term 'bewitched' (Acts 8:9,11) imply about Simon’s influence in Samaria in historical-cultural context?
options: He exercised magical arts that impressed and controlled people, reflecting common ancient Near Eastern beliefs in sorcery
He was a political leader who used rhetoric
He was a religious teacher promoting Jewish law
He was a merchant who bribed officials
questions.correctAnswer: He exercised magical arts that impressed and controlled people, reflecting common ancient Near Eastern beliefs in sorcery
questions.explanation: The term 'bewitched' indicates Simon’s use of sorcery, a practice widely feared and respected in the ancient Near East, which gave him social influence.

questions.question: What theme in Acts 8 is foreshadowed by the scattering of believers and Philip’s ministry in Samaria?
options: The expansion of the gospel beyond Jerusalem to the Gentile world
The establishment of a new Jewish sect
The decline of the Christian movement
The fulfillment of Mosaic Law rituals
questions.correctAnswer: The expansion of the gospel beyond Jerusalem to the Gentile world
questions.explanation: The scattering of believers in Acts 8:1 and Philip’s preaching in Samaria signal the gospel’s spread beyond Jewish boundaries, a key theme in Acts.

questions.question: Which Old Testament prophet’s writings does the Ethiopian eunuch read and inquire about in Acts 8?
options: Esaias (Isaiah)
Jeremiah
Ezekiel
Daniel
questions.correctAnswer: Esaias (Isaiah)
questions.explanation: Acts 8:28-30 shows the eunuch reading the prophet Esaias, the Greek name for Isaiah, specifically Isaiah 53 about the suffering servant.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 8 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 8 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the initial cause of the scattering of the believers from Jerusalem?
options: A great persecution against the church
A famine in Jerusalem
A Roman decree to disperse the Christians
An angel's command to spread the gospel
questions.correctAnswer: A great persecution against the church
questions.explanation: Acts 8:1 states that a great persecution against the church in Jerusalem caused the believers to be scattered. This reflects the biblical theme of suffering leading to the spread of the gospel (see also Matthew 10:16-23; John 16:2; 2 Timothy 3:12; 1 Peter 4:12-16).

questions.question: Who was responsible for carrying Stephen to his burial?
options: Devout men
The apostles
Saul and his companions
The priests
questions.correctAnswer: Devout men
questions.explanation: Acts 8:2 notes that devout men carried Stephen to his burial and made great lamentation over him, showing the respect believers had for the first martyr. This reflects the honor given to those who die for their faith (see Hebrews 11:4; Revelation 6:9; 2 Timothy 4:7-8; John 15:18-21).

questions.question: What was Saul's role regarding the church before his conversion?
options: He made havoc of the church, imprisoning men and women
He preached the gospel in synagogues
He financially supported the believers
He remained neutral
questions.correctAnswer: He made havoc of the church, imprisoning men and women
questions.explanation: Acts 8:3 describes Saul's violent opposition to the church by entering houses and imprisoning believers. This demonstrates the human sinfulness and opposition to God's kingdom before conversion (see also Philippians 3:6; 1 Timothy 1:13; Galatians 1:13-14; John 16:2).

questions.question: What was the primary activity of those scattered after the persecution?
options: Preaching the word everywhere
Seeking refuge in other cities
Building new churches
Returning to Jerusalem secretly
questions.correctAnswer: Preaching the word everywhere
questions.explanation: Acts 8:4 reveals that those scattered preached the word everywhere, showing how persecution can advance the gospel. This aligns with Jesus' command to make disciples of all nations (Matthew 28:19-20; Mark 16:15; Romans 10:14-15; 2 Corinthians 5:18-20).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the people in Samaria to Philip's preaching?
options: They gave heed with one accord, hearing and seeing miracles
They rejected him and arrested him
They remained indifferent
They demanded signs and wonders
questions.correctAnswer: They gave heed with one accord, hearing and seeing miracles
questions.explanation: Acts 8:6 describes the unified attention of the people to Philip's message combined with miracles, underscoring the Holy Spirit's power to confirm the gospel (see Hebrews 2:4; John 14:12; Mark 16:20; Romans 15:18-19).

questions.question: Which of the following did NOT occur during Philip's ministry in Samaria?
options: Many were healed of palsies and lameness
Unclean spirits came out of many possessed
Simon was immediately baptized before believing
There was great joy in the city
questions.correctAnswer: Simon was immediately baptized before believing
questions.explanation: Acts 8:7-8 show many healings and great joy, but Simon believed first before baptism (Acts 8:13). This sequence reflects the biblical pattern of faith preceding baptism (see Acts 16:31-34; Romans 6:3-4; Mark 16:16; Galatians 3:27).

questions.question: What was Simon's reputation before believing the gospel?
options: A sorcerer who bewitched the people
A respected Pharisee
A Roman official
A devout Jew from Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: A sorcerer who bewitched the people
questions.explanation: Acts 8:9-11 describes Simon as a sorcerer who claimed to be great and had bewitched the people, illustrating the contrast between false signs and true miracles (see Deuteronomy 18:10-12; 2 Corinthians 11:13-15; Galatians 5:20; Revelation 21:8).

questions.question: Why did the apostles send Peter and John to Samaria?
options: Because Samaria had received the word of God and they wanted to pray for them to receive the Holy Ghost
To rebuke Philip for preaching in Samaria
To establish a new church building
To collect offerings for Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Because Samaria had received the word of God and they wanted to pray for them to receive the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Acts 8:14-15 shows that the apostles sent Peter and John to pray for new believers to receive the Holy Spirit, highlighting the role of apostolic authority and the Spirit's essential work (see John 20:22; Luke 24:49; Acts 2:38; Ephesians 1:13-14).

questions.question: What did Simon try to purchase from the apostles?
options: The power to give the Holy Ghost by laying on of hands
A position of leadership in the church
The right to baptize others
The ability to perform miracles
questions.correctAnswer: The power to give the Holy Ghost by laying on of hands
questions.explanation: Acts 8:18-19 records Simon’s attempt to buy the apostolic gift of conferring the Holy Spirit, demonstrating a misunderstanding of grace and spiritual gifts (see Ephesians 2:8-9; 1 Corinthians 12:4-11; James 1:17; 2 Timothy 1:6).

questions.question: What was Peter's rebuke to Simon regarding his offer to buy the power of God?
options: Thy money perish with thee, because thou hast thought that the gift of God may be purchased with money
You must be baptized again to receive true power
You are not worthy to be a believer
You should leave the church immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Thy money perish with thee, because thou hast thought that the gift of God may be purchased with money
questions.explanation: In Acts 8:20, Peter rebukes Simon for thinking God's gifts can be bought, emphasizing that salvation and spiritual gifts are freely given by grace (see Romans 6:23; Isaiah 55:1; Ephesians 2:8-9; 2 Corinthians 9:15).

questions.question: What condition did Peter say Simon needed to do after his sin?
options: Repent of this thy wickedness and pray for forgiveness
Leave the church and never return
Offer money to the poor
Confess before the elders
questions.correctAnswer: Repent of this thy wickedness and pray for forgiveness
questions.explanation: Acts 8:22 commands Simon to repent and pray for forgiveness, affirming the biblical doctrine of repentance as necessary for restoration (see Acts 3:19; 1 John 1:9; Luke 13:3; 2 Chronicles 7:14).

questions.question: What was the Ethiopian eunuch doing when Philip joined him?
options: Reading the prophet Esaias (Isaiah) in his chariot
Praying at the temple
Sacrificing at the altar
Resting by the roadside
questions.correctAnswer: Reading the prophet Esaias (Isaiah) in his chariot
questions.explanation: Acts 8:27-28 shows the eunuch reading Isaiah in his chariot, illustrating the role of Old Testament prophecy in pointing to Christ and the necessity of guidance for understanding Scripture (see Luke 24:27,44; John 5:39; Isaiah 53; 2 Timothy 3:16-17).

questions.question: What scripture was the eunuch reading when Philip approached him?
options: "He was led as a sheep to the slaughter; and like a lamb dumb before his shearer"
"The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want"
"Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord"
"The stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone"
questions.correctAnswer: "He was led as a sheep to the slaughter; and like a lamb dumb before his shearer"
questions.explanation: Acts 8:32-33 quotes Isaiah 53:7-8, a messianic prophecy describing Jesus' innocent suffering, highlighting the Christological fulfillment in the gospel (see Isaiah 53; 1 Peter 2:22-25; John 1:29; Hebrews 9:28).

questions.question: What was the eunuch's response to Philip's explanation of the scripture?
options: He requested baptism immediately
He rejected the message
He asked to meet the apostles
He returned to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: He requested baptism immediately
questions.explanation: Acts 8:36-38 shows the eunuch's immediate desire to be baptized after understanding the gospel, demonstrating the biblical sequence of faith and baptism as part of salvation (see Mark 16:16; Romans 6:3-4; Acts 2:41; Galatians 3:27).

questions.question: What happened to Philip after baptizing the Ethiopian eunuch?
options: The Spirit of the Lord caught him away
He was arrested by authorities
He stayed with the eunuch for several days
He returned immediately to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of the Lord caught him away
questions.explanation: Acts 8:39 recounts that after baptism, the Holy Spirit transported Philip away, showing divine guidance and empowerment for mission (see Acts 1:8; Ezekiel 3:12-14; John 16:13; 2 Corinthians 12:2-4).
